awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Evolution of Dwarf Galaxies - A Comprehensive View of the Magellanic Clouds
awd_abstract_narration:
The investigators lead large imaging and spectroscopic surveys of two nearby dwarf galaxies, the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds.  While most dwarf galaxies are challenging to study because they are intrinsically faint, the Magellanic Clouds (MCs) are nearby and serve as a unique laboratory to study the structure and dynamics of low-mass galaxies.  The investigators will utilize the power of both the imaging Survey of the MAgellanic Stellar History (SMASH) and high-resolution spectroscopy from the Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE) to substantially improve our knowledge of the MCs.

The investigators will create large maps of the element abundance patterns and gradients across both MCs.  With this combination of observations, they hope to understand the elemental abundance changes over time and space in the MCs by using nuclear reaction models and drawing comparisons to simulations.   

In addition, the investigators will engage the public in state-of-the art research through a citizen science project called "The APOGEE Spectral Zoo", which will be developed on the Zooniverse platform. Citizens will visually inspect samples of the two million individual APOGEE spectra - including time series spectra on almost all sources - and classify the APOGEE targets, flagging any that appear to have interesting or "abnormal" spectral features that are not currently recognized in the current automated APOGEE spectral analysis pipeline. These citizen scientists will learn many aspects of astronomy, including stars with emission line spectra, time variable objects, double-line spectroscopic binary stars, chemically peculiar stars and cataclysmic variables. The citizens will enhance the research by producing a complementary classification of stars in the survey.  The investigator will check the accuracy of the pipeline analysis by comparison with the citizen scientists classifications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Low-mass dwarf galaxies are the most numerous star systems in the universe and are fundamental pieces in the assembly of Milky Way-sized galaxies. Despite their ubiquity, dwarf galaxies are incredibly difficult to study because even the closest examples are incredibly faint. Fortunately, two --- the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds (MCs) -- are not only prominent companions to our own Milky Way galaxy, but technology has advanced to where they are now accessible for systematic exploration on a star-by-star basis. Thus, the MCs represent an essential and unique laboratory whose relic stellar populations can be used to uncover the chemical and dynamical evolution of both dwarf and large galaxies. Interestingly, we now believe that the MCs are just now falling into the Milky Way, so they likely spent most of their lives as an isolated pair of dwarf galaxies orbiting one another but otherwise evolving in a low-density part of the Universe. In this regard, they have interesting differences with other “large” dwarf galaxies, like the Sagittarius, Fornax, and Gaia-Enceladus systems, that have significantly longer histories as satellites of the Milky Way. 


By utilizing the power of several new, expansive, wide-field surveys, we have studied the chemo-dynamical structure and evolution of the MCs in unprecedented detail. We exploited the extensive and deep photometry taken with the 4-m Blanco telescope in Chile as part of the Survey of the MAgellanic Stellar History (SMASH) combined with high-resolution spectroscopy from the Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE) taken on the 2.5-m duPont telescope and the astrometric data provided by the European Space Agency’s Gaia satellite. What we have learned about the MCs has created a baseline of knowledge for systems that are the archetypes of a class of dwarf galaxy morphology (the so-called "Magellanic Irregulars"), and has provided insights into how the interactions of pairs of dwarf galaxies impact their evolution. 


For example, we have shown that the Clouds experienced a very low efficiency in forming stars early-on in their evolution --- almost 50x lower than did the MW, but more surprisingly, even more slowly than other dwarf galaxies (Sagittarius, Fornax, Gaia-Enceladus), even though the MCs are 10-100x more massive. We believe that this initially counterintuitive result of a “lazier” start to star formation is explained by the fact that, probably unlike the other dwarf galaxies, the MCs initially formed and evolved in an isolated environment, far from a large galaxy like the Milky Way, whose large gravity can strongly influence dwarf galaxies in a number of ways. This difference in the history of star formation demonstrates the importance of the environment on the evolution of dwarf galaxies. 


We also extensively explored the variations in the chemical composition of stars as a function of their position in the MCs and have found that there have been some dramatic changes in the abundance variations in recent times. The timing of this change corresponds to the age of a large starburst in the Large MC, and likely is the result of a recent close interaction of the two MCs with one another. 


We have also contributed to the understanding of dwarf galaxy interactions and their effect on dwarf galaxy evolution with a number of analyses of various stellar overdensities ("substructures") that have recently been discovered in the peripheries of the MCs. We find that the chemistry and dynamics of the stars in these substructures indicate an origin as material stripped out of one or the other of the MCs as a result of their mutual interaction during close passes to one another, or as destroyed remains of even smaller dwarf galaxies that were originally satellites of the MCs. This helps resolve the origin of much of the Magellanic periphery, which has been the subject of ongoing debates for over a decade. 


Further evidence that the Clouds are still experiencing such dramatic mass loss comes from our finding that in the foreground of the East side of the Small MC there is a population of stars that seem to have been recently pulled out of that galaxy’s center, again, likely a result of a dramatic encounter with the Large MC. 


All of these results are providing deeper insights into the dynamical evolution of the Magellanic Clouds as a tightly coupled pair of coevolving and interacting dwarf galaxies both before and on their way to falling into the Milky Way. This work has thus opened an interesting new window into the hierarchical nature of galaxy growth, where we have obtained detailed snapshots of what happens to smaller galactic subunits before they are subsumed into much larger, MW-like systems.
